substitute.translation[0].definitions[0]: someone who does someone else’s job for a limited period of time, especially in a sports team or school
Germany brought on a substitute at half time.
The coach has to find a substitute for Tim.
substitute.translation[0].definitions[1]: a person or thing that you use instead of the one that you usually have, because the usual one is not available
substitute.translation[1].definitions[0]: to use something new or different instead of something else
The recipe says you can substitute yoghurt for the sour cream.
substitute.translation[1].definitions[1]: to do someone’s job until the person who usually does it is able to do it again
Bill substituted for Larry, who was off sick.
substitute.translation[1].definitions[2]: to replace someone with another person, especially another player
Michael Owen had to be substituted after 20 minutes on the field.
substitute.translation[2].definitions[0]: something new or different that can be used instead of something else
Sugar substitutes are used by the soft drinks industry.
Training is important but it is no substitute for (=cannot take the place of) experience.
substitute.translation[2].definitions[1]: someone who does someone else’s job for a limited period of time
We need to find a substitute while she is sick.
substitute.translation[3].definitions[0]: to use or do something new or different instead of something else
Corporations have been able to avoid some tax by substituting debt for equity.
Byproducts are reduced if a different bleaching agent is substituted for pure chlorine.
substitute.translation[3].definitions[1]: to be used or done instead of something else
Synthetic fuels are liquids or gases which may be substituted for oil products or natural gas.
substitute.translation[3].definitions[2]: to do someone’s job until the person who usually does it is able to do it again
Bill substituted for Larry who was off sick.
